review.title: Robust Energy Storage Scheduling for Imbalance Reduction of Strategically Formed Energy Balancing Groups
review.abstract: Imbalance (on-line energy gap between contracted supply and actual demand, and associated cost) reduction is going to be a crucial service for a Power Producer and Supplier (PPS) in the deregulated energy market. PPS requires forward market interactions to procure energy as precisely as possible in order to reduce imbalance energy. This paper presents, 1) (off-line) an effective demand aggregation based strategy for creating a number of balancing groups that leads to higher predictability of group-wise aggregated demand, 2) (on-line) a robust energy storage scheduling that minimizes the imbalance for a particular balancing group considering the demand prediction uncertainty. The group formation is performed by a Probabilistic Programming approach using Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method after applied on the historical demand statistics. Apart from the group formation, the aggregation strategy (with the help of Bayesian Inference) also clears out the upper-limit of the required storage capacity for a formed group, fraction of which is to be utilized in on-line operation. For on-line operation, a robust energy storage scheduling method is proposed that minimizes expected imbalance energy and cost (a non-linear function of imbalance energy) while incorporating the demand uncertainty of a particular group. The proposed methods are applied on the real apartment buildings' demand data in Tokyo, Japan. Simulation results are presented to verify the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

Group formation is carried out through a probabilistic programming approach using the Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method after application to historical demand statistics. sections.heading: 4. Numerical Simulations and Discussions
sections.text: In this section, numerical simulations, analysis, results and discussions related to the formation of balance group and robust CD planning are presented. A total of 103 Tokyo apartments will be taken as customers and their demand data will be used for analysis. Specifically, the demand data from January and February 2013 will be taken and broken down into two phases 1. Analysis and training phase: Data from January 1 to January 20 will be used to perform balance group building and train the initial forecast model (SVR).2. Optimization and simulation phase: Data from January 21 to February 28 will be used to perform simulations of robust and online CD planning. Note that although the initial SVR model will be trained using demand data from January 1 to 20 (i.e. 20 days), the SVR model will be updated based on the immediate past 20-day demand data (from the simulation day).

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we propose novel solutions to two of the fundamental but interrelated problems of PPS. The first concerns the formation of energy-based balance groups within a particular class of customers. In this paper, multi-family houses are considered as customers. To solve the group-building problem, we apply a Bayesian MCMC-based dividend strategy that includes a statistical measure (periodic standard deviation of demand from each customer) and generates a number of balance groups. The purpose of creating a balance group is to select similar customers whose aggregate demand has greater predictability, which helps PPS plan the supply contract. Bayesian MCMC proves to be an effective aggregation strategy that not only provides appropriate grouping, but also provides important demand-centric insights into each group (e.g. the ceiling on the storage capacity required to reduce the imbalance of actual demand).
